newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ shares claw back initial weakness, end level.
newsitem.headline: NZ shares claw back initial weakness, end level.

text.p: * NZ share prices claw back from initial weakness
* Ports re-rated after Port of Tauranga result
* Market withstands weakness abroad, but on light volume.
Price movements at close
LAST CHG
144 nil * NZSE-40 cap index -0.90 at 2,219.97
328 nil * NZSC cap index +33.61 at 4,474.01
382 + 2 * Volume NZ$28 million. Futures -1 at 1,122
685 nil * Other movers - +12 +13
New Zealand share prices clawed their way back from initial weakness to end square on Tuesday but on very light volume.

The NZSE-40 Capital Index was down just 0.90 of a point to 2,219.97 on light volume but Charles Batchelor at First NZ Capital said it was a reasonable peformance given weakness in overseas markets and rising domestic bond yields.
"It started off on the back foot then got back to being virtually zero change. It really was quite well supported," Batchelor said.
The index had gone through a 2,209.99 to 2,219.97 range.
Ports continued to be the highlight after Port of Tauranga's stronger-than-expected result on Monday, which today meant the stock was re-rated up by 6.3 percent or 12 cents to NZ$2.04.
Fellow provincial port operator Northland appeared to coat-tail Tauranga, also gaining 6.3 percent and ending 13 cents higher at NZ$2.20.
Brokers said Northland appeared to have missed out in the recent re-rating of the sector.
Ports of Auckland also gained, by 10 cents to NZ$5.35, while in the South Island, Lyttleton Port firmed two to NZ$1.46.

Not so lucky was Designer Textiles, which was again singled out for selling. Designer ended five cents or 4.8 percent down to close at NZ$1.00 after revising down its 1996/7 profit forecasts. - James Gray (64 9 302 1253)
